datatype.definition: Computational gene function prediction can serve to focus experimental resources on high-priority experimental tasks. FuncBase is a web resource for viewing quantitative machine learning-based gene function annotations. Quantitative annotations of genes, including fungal and mammalian genes, with Gene Ontology terms are accompanied by a community feedback system. Evidence underlying function annotations is shown. FuncBase provides links to external resources, and may be accessed directly or via links from species-specific databases. This collection references yeast.

resource.dataInfo: FuncBase Yeast at Harvard Medical School
resource.dataInstitution: Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts

datatype.name: YDPM

synonyms.synonym: Yeast Deletion Project and Proteomics of Mitochondria Database

datatype.definition: The YDPM database serves to support the Yeast Deletion and the Mitochondrial Proteomics Project. The project aims to increase the understanding of mitochondrial function and biogenesis in the context of the cell. In the Deletion Project, strains from the deletion collection were monitored under 9 different media conditions selected for the study of mitochondrial function. The YDPM database contains both the raw data and growth rates calculated for each strain in each media condition.

resource.dataInfo: YDPM at Stanford University School of Medicine
resource.dataInstitution: Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, California

datatype.name: WormBase RNAi
datatype.definition: WormBase is an online bioinformatics database of the biology and genome of the model organism Caenorhabditis elegans and related nematodes. It is used by the C. elegans research community both as an information resource and as a mode to publish and distribute their results. This collection references RNAi experiments, detailing target and phenotypes.

resource.dataInfo: WormBase RNAi at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory
resource.dataInstitution: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring, Harbor New York

datatype.name: FunCat
datatype.definition: The Functional Catalogue (FunCat) is a hierarchically structured, organism-independent, flexible and scalable controlled classification system enabling the functional description of proteins from any organism. It has been applied for the manual annotation of prokaryotes, fungi, plants and animals.

resource.dataInstitution: Institute for Bioinformatics (MIPS), GSF National Research Center for Environment and Health, Neuherberg

datatype.name: PASS2

synonyms.synonym: Protein Alignments organised as Structural Superfamilies

datatype.definition: The PASS2 database provides alignments of proteins related at the superfamily level and are characterized by low sequence identity.

resource.dataInfo: PASS2 at National centre for Biological Sciences (India)
resource.dataInstitution: National centre for Biological Sciences, TIFR, GKVK campus, Bangalore, Karnataka

datatype.name: ICEberg element
datatype.definition: ICEberg (Integrative and conjugative elements) is a database of integrative and conjugative elements (ICEs) found in bacteria. ICEs are conjugative self-transmissible elements that can integrate into and excise from a host chromosome, and can carry likely virulence determinants, antibiotic-resistant factors and/or genes coding for other beneficial traits. It contains details of ICEs found in representatives bacterial species, and which are organised as families. This collection references ICE elements.

resource.dataInfo: ICEberg element at Shanghai Jiaotong University
resource.dataInstitution: State Key Laboratory of Microbial Metabolism and School of Life Sciences &amp;amp;amp; Biotechnology, Shanghai Jiaotong University, Shanghai

datatype.name: ICEberg family
datatype.definition: ICEberg (Integrative and conjugative elements) is a database of integrative and conjugative elements (ICEs) found in bacteria. ICEs are conjugative self-transmissible elements that can integrate into and excise from a host chromosome, and can carry likely virulence determinants, antibiotic-resistant factors and/or genes coding for other beneficial traits. It contains details of ICEs found in representatives bacterial species, and which are organised as families. This collection references ICE families.

resource.dataInfo: ICEberg family at Shanghai Jiaotong University
resource.dataInstitution: State Key Laboratory of Microbial Metabolism and School of Life Sciences &amp; Biotechnology, Shanghai Jiaotong University, Shanghai

datatype.name: VFDB Genus
datatype.definition: VFDB is a repository of virulence factors (VFs) of pathogenic bacteria.This collection references VF information by Genus.

resource.dataInfo: VFDB Genus at Institute of Pathogen Biology
resource.dataInstitution: State Key Laboratory for Molecular Virology and Genetic Engineering, Institute of Pathogen Biology, Chinese Academy Medical Sciences and Peking Union Medical College, Beijing

datatype.name: VFDB Gene
datatype.definition: VFDB is a repository of virulence factors (VFs) of pathogenic bacteria.This collection references VF genes.

resource.dataInfo: VFDB Gene at Institute of Pathogen Biology
resource.dataInstitution: State Key Laboratory for Molecular Virology and Genetic Engineering, Institute of Pathogen Biology, Chinese Academy Medical Sciences and Peking Union Medical College, Beijing

datatype.name: MeSH 2013
datatype.definition: MeSH (Medical Subject Headings) is the National Library of Medicine's controlled vocabulary thesaurus. It consists of sets of terms naming descriptors in a hierarchical structure that permits searching at various levels of specificity. This thesaurus is used by NLM for indexing articles from biomedical journals, cataloging of books, documents, etc. This collection references MeSH terms published in 2013.

resource.dataInfo: MeSH 2013 at National Library of Medicine
resource.dataInstitution: U.S. National Library of Medicine, National Institute of Health, Maryland

restriction.statement: Records accessed through MESH may include content that itself has some copyright restriction when reproduced.

datatype.name: KEGG Module
datatype.definition: KEGG Modules are manually defined functional units used in the annotation and biological interpretation of sequenced genomes. Each module corresponds to a set of 'KEGG Orthology' (MIR:00000116) entries. KEGG Modules can represent pathway, structural, functional or signature modules.

resource.dataInfo: KEGG Module at Kyoto University Bioinformatics Center
resource.dataInstitution: Department of Computational Biology, University of Tokyo, Tokyo

datatype.name: KEGG Disease
datatype.definition: The KEGG DISEASE database is a collection of disease entries capturing knowledge on genetic and environmental perturbations. Each disease entry contains a list of known genetic factors (disease genes), environmental factors, diagnostic markers, and therapeutic drugs. Diseases are viewed as perturbed states of the molecular system, and drugs as perturbants to the molecular system.

resource.dataInfo: KEGG Disease at Kyoto University Bioinformatics Center
resource.dataInstitution: Kyoto University Bioinformatics Center, Kyoto

datatype.name: MedlinePlus
datatype.definition: MedlinePlus is the National Institutes of Health's Web site for patients and their families and friends. Produced by the National Library of Medicine, it provides information about diseases, conditions, and wellness issues using non-technical terms and language.

resource.dataInstitution: NCBI, NIH, Bethesda, Maryland

datatype.name: LigandBox
datatype.definition: LigandBox is a database of 3D compound structures. Compound information is collected from the catalogues of various commercial suppliers, with approved drugs and biochemical compounds taken from KEGG and PDB databases. Each chemical compound in the database has several 3D conformers with hydrogen atoms and atomic charges, which are ready to be docked into receptors using docking programs. Various physical properties, such as aqueous solubility (LogS) and carcinogenicity have also been calculated to characterize the ADME-Tox properties of the compounds.

resource.dataInstitution: nstitute for Protein Research, Osaka University and Fujitsu Kyushu R&D Center, Life Science Systems Dept., Fujitsu

datatype.name: GlycoEpitope
datatype.definition: GlycoEpitope is a database containing useful information about carbohydrate antigens (glyco-epitopes) and the antibodies (polyclonal or monoclonal) that can be used to analyze their expression. This collection references Glycoepitopes.

resource.dataInstitution: Kawasaki laboratory, Research Center for Glycobiotechnology, Ritsumeikan University

datatype.name: JCGGDB

synonyms.synonym: Japan Consortium for Glycobiology and Glycotechnology DataBase

datatype.definition: JCGGDB (Japan Consortium for Glycobiology and Glycotechnology DataBase) is a database that aims to integrate all glycan-related data held in various repositories in Japan. This includes databases for large-quantity synthesis of glycogenes and glycans, analysis and detection of glycan structure and glycoprotein, glycan-related differentiation markers, glycan functions, glycan-related diseases and transgenic and knockout animals, etc.

resource.dataInstitution: Advanced Science Institute(ASI), Chemical Biology Department Systems Glycobiology research Group, Saitama

datatype.name: NONCODE v4 Gene
datatype.definition: NONCODE is a database of expression and functional lncRNA (long noncoding RNA) data obtained from microarray studies. LncRNAs have been shown to play key roles in various biological processes such as imprinting control, circuitry controlling pluripotency and differentiation, immune responses and chromosome dynamics. The collection references NONCODE version 4 and relates to gene regions.

resource.dataInfo: NONCODE v4 Gene at Chinese Academy of Sciences
resource.dataInstitution: Bioinformatics Research Group, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing

datatype.name: NONCODE v4 Transcript
datatype.definition: NONCODE is a database of expression and functional lncRNA (long noncoding RNA) data obtained from microarray studies. LncRNAs have been shown to play key roles in various biological processes such as imprinting control, circuitry controlling pluripotency and differentiation, immune responses and chromosome dynamics. The collection references NONCODE version 4 and relates to individual transcripts.

resource.dataInfo: NONCODE v4 Transcript at Chinese Academy of Sciences
resource.dataInstitution: Bioinformatics Research Group, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing

datatype.name: Oryzabase Gene
datatype.definition: Oryzabase provides a view of rice (Oryza sativa) as a model monocot plant by integrating biological data with molecular genomic information. It contains information about rice development and anatomy, rice mutants, and genetic resources, especially for wild varieties of rice. Developmental and anatomical descriptions include in situ gene expression data serving as stage and tissue markers. This collection references gene information.

resource.dataInfo: Oryzabase v4 Gene at National Institute of Genetics (Japan)
resource.dataInstitution: Genetic Strains Research Center, National Institute of Genetics, Mishima, Shizuoka

It contains information about rice development and anatomy, rice mutants, and genetic resources, especially for wild varieties of rice. Developmental and anatomical descriptions include in situ gene expression data serving as stage and tissue markers. This collection references mutant strain information.

resource.dataInfo: Oryzabase v4 Mutant at National Institute of Genetics (Japan)
resource.dataInstitution: Genetic Strains Research Center, National Institute of Genetics, Mishima, Shizuoka

It contains information about rice development and anatomy, rice mutants, and genetic resources, especially for wild varieties of rice. Developmental and anatomical descriptions include in situ gene expression data serving as stage and tissue markers. This collection references wild strain information.

datatype.name: Oryza Tag Line
datatype.definition: Oryza Tag Line is a database that was developed to collect information generated from the characterization of rice (Oryza sativa L cv. Nipponbare) insertion lines resulting in potential gene disruptions. It collates morpho-physiological alterations observed during field evaluation, with each insertion line documented through a generic passport data including production records, seed stocks and FST information.

resource.dataInstitution: CIRAD-INRA-SUPAGRO-UMII, Biological Systems Department, Montpellier

datatype.name: Gene Wiki
datatype.definition: The Gene Wiki is project which seeks to provide detailed information on human genes. Initial 'stub' articles are created in an automated manner, with further information added by the community. Gene Wiki can be accessed in wikipedia using Gene identifiers from NCBI.

resource.dataInstitution: Wikimedia Foundation, San Francisco, California

restriction.statement: This collection is a subset of NCBI gene (MIR:00000069), accessed through BioGPS.

datatype.name: PaxDb Organism
datatype.definition: PaxDb is a resource dedicated to integrating information on absolute protein abundance levels across different organisms. Publicly available experimental data are mapped onto a common namespace and, in the case of tandem mass spectrometry data, re-processed using a standardized spectral counting pipeline. Data sets are scored and ranked to assess consistency against externally provided protein-network information. PaxDb provides whole-organism data as well as tissue-resolved data, for numerous proteins. This collection references protein abundance information by species.

resource.dataInfo: PaxDb v3 at University of Zurich
resource.dataInstitution: Institute of Molecular Life Sciences, University of Zurich, Zurich

datatype.name: PaxDb Protein
datatype.definition: PaxDb is a resource dedicated to integrating information on absolute protein abundance levels across different organisms. Publicly available experimental data are mapped onto a common namespace and, in the case of tandem mass spectrometry data, re-processed using a standardized spectral counting pipeline. Data sets are scored and ranked to assess consistency against externally provided protein-network information. PaxDb provides whole-organism data as well as tissue-resolved data, for numerous proteins. This collection references individual protein abundance levels.

resource.dataInfo: PaxDb v3 at University of Zurich
resource.dataInstitution: Institute of Molecular Life Sciences, University of Zurich, Zurich

datatype.name: Protein Data Bank Ligand
datatype.definition: The Protein Data Bank is the single worldwide archive of structural data of biological macromolecules. This collection references ligands.

resource.dataInstitution: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

tagDefinition.name: annotation
tagDefinition.definition: Descriptive text, usually added by an author or curator, that provides extra information that may be missing or not immediately evident.

tagDefinition.name: assay
tagDefinition.definition: A collection that specifies direct assay conditions and/or provides experimental results.

tagDefinition.name: bibliography
tagDefinition.definition: A citation list which supports the information provided. This may include books, publications in journal, or URL links.

tagDefinition.name: catalogue
tagDefinition.definition: A data collection providing information on commercially available products.

tagDefinition.name: chemical
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections with this tag reference data pertaining to chemical compounds and substances.

tagDefinition.name: classification
tagDefinition.definition: A classification scheme which does not necessarily depict a relationship between different groups, but only between individuals within a group.

tagDefinition.name: clustering
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections with this tag contain data which has been processed in such a way as to generate subsets (clusters) within which some trait should be shared.

tagDefinition.name: controlled vocabulary
tagDefinition.definition: Controlled vocabularies provide predefined and authorised terms for shared use by a community, providing a means to organise knowledge for subsequent processing.

tagDefinition.name: disease
tagDefinition.definition: A disease is an abnormal condition of an organism that impairs bodily functions and can be deadly. It is also defined as a way of the body harming itself in an abnormal way, associated with specific symptoms and signs. [wikipedia]

tagDefinition.name: disorder
tagDefinition.definition: The term "disorder" is often considered more value-neutral than the term "disease" [wikipedia]. Hence it may have no attributable signs or symptoms.

tagDefinition.name: DNA
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections with this tag reference data pertaining to deoxyribonucleic acid.

tagDefinition.name: domain
tagDefinition.definition: A domain is a protein subsequence that forms a three-dimensional structure, and can provide specific catalytic or binding sites as found in enzymes or regulatory proteins. A specific domain may appear in a variety of evolutionarily related proteins.

tagDefinition.name: drug
tagDefinition.definition: A drug, broadly speaking, is any chemical substance that, when absorbed into the body of a living organism, alters normal bodily function [wikipedia].Toxins are included in this category.

tagDefinition.name: encyclopedia
tagDefinition.definition: A generic knowledge repository not restricted to a particular domain, and which is primarily used for reference purposes.

tagDefinition.name: enzyme
tagDefinition.definition: An enzyme is a biological catalyst of a chemical reaction. Most enzymes are proteins.

tagDefinition.name: eukaryotic
tagDefinition.definition: Data collection pertaining to eukaryotic cells, which are differentiated from prokaryotic cells by the presence of a nucleus. This group includes human, plant, and fungal cells.

tagDefinition.name: expression
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections associated with this tag pertain to the measurement of gene expression, often through the use of microarray techniques, and usually in quantitative fashion.

tagDefinition.name: fungal
tagDefinition.definition: Data collection pertaining to species of fungi.

tagDefinition.name: gene
tagDefinition.definition: Genes are discrete subsequences of genomic DNA and correspond to a unit of inheritance [based on wikipedia]. A data collection tagged 'gene' should include gene information in addition to purely sequence-oriented data.

tagDefinition.name: genome
tagDefinition.definition: A genome is the full compliment of hereditary information (usually DNA) for a given organism, and includes coding and non-coding sequences where applicable. 'Genome' tagged data collections are those whose information is derived from genome level sequencing projects.

tagDefinition.name: human
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections labelled 'human' should contain human centric data.

tagDefinition.name: image library
tagDefinition.definition: A repository of static images or animations.

tagDefinition.name: immunogenetics
tagDefinition.definition: A branch of research focused upon the relationship between one's genetics and immune response.

tagDefinition.name: interaction
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections tagged 'interaction' should contain information relating to molecular interaction data, often protein-protein.

tagDefinition.name: kinetics
tagDefinition.definition: Kinetics is the study of rates of reactions or chemical processes. Data collections tagged 'kinetics' should provide information such as rate laws and rate constants.

tagDefinition.name: lipid
tagDefinition.definition: Data collection pertaining to lipids, which are lipophilic, naturally-occurring molecules.

tagDefinition.name: mammalian
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections labelled 'mammalian' should contain mammal centric data.

tagDefinition.name: mass spectrometry
tagDefinition.definition: Mass spectrometry is an analytical technique that identifies the chemical composition of a compound or sample on the basis of the mass-to-charge ratio of charged particles. [Wikipedia]

tagDefinition.name: metabolite
tagDefinition.definition: Metabolites are the intermediates and products of metabolism. The term metabolite is usually restricted to small molecules. A primary metabolite is directly involved in normal growth, development, and reproduction. A secondary metabolite is not directly involved in those processes, but usually has an important ecological function. Examples include antibiotics and pigments.

tagDefinition.name: microarray
tagDefinition.definition: Microarray is a high-throughput technology often used to measure gene expression.

tagDefinition.name: microbial
tagDefinition.definition: Datatype relating to bacterial species

tagDefinition.name: model
tagDefinition.definition: Data collection pertaining to mathematical models, encoded in a form that allows their use in simulation software.

tagDefinition.name: neuroscience
tagDefinition.definition: Scientific study of the nervous system.

tagDefinition.name: nucleotide
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections tagged with 'nucleotide' refer to DNA and RNA molecules.

tagDefinition.name: ontology
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections tagged with 'ontology' reference those ontologies that are used in the life sciences.

tagDefinition.name: pathway
tagDefinition.definition: Series of sequential chemical reactions that are referred to collectively.

tagDefinition.name: pharmacogenomics
tagDefinition.definition: Pharmacogenomics is the branch of pharmacology which deals with the influence of genetic variation on drug response in patients by correlating gene expression or single-nucleotide polymorphisms with a drug's efficacy or toxicity. [wiki]

tagDefinition.name: phenotype
tagDefinition.definition: A phenotype is any observable characteristic of an organism, such as its morphology, development, biochemical or physiological properties, or behaviour [wikipedia].

tagDefinition.name: plant
tagDefinition.definition: Dataype type should be focused on plant species

tagDefinition.name: polysaccharide
tagDefinition.definition: Polysaccharides are polymeric carbohydrate structures, formed of repeating units (either mono- or di-saccharides) joined together by glycosidic bonds. These structures are often linear, but may contain various degrees of branching. Polysaccharides are often quite heterogeneous, containing slight modifications of the repeating unit. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polysaccharide]

tagDefinition.name: protein
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections with this tag reference data pertaining to proteins.

tagDefinition.name: reaction
tagDefinition.definition: A single chemical reaction which yields products which are, generally, different from the reactants. Data collections tagged 'reaction' focus on individual chemical reactions.

tagDefinition.name: registry
tagDefinition.definition: A data collection within which information is registered or collated, effectively providing a catalogue for (community) reference purposes.

tagDefinition.name: sequence
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections tagged 'sequence' reference sequence data, such as DNA, RNA or protein.

tagDefinition.name: strain
tagDefinition.definition: A genetic variant of a particular organism.

tagDefinition.name: structure
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections with the 'structure' tag should reference chemical or 3-dimensional structure.

tagDefinition.name: taxonomy
tagDefinition.definition: A classification scheme, arranged in a hierarchical structure, that depicts parent-child relationships between its members.

tagDefinition.name: viral
tagDefinition.definition: Data collection pertaining to virus information.
